awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Building Urban Community Networks for Sustainable Cities in Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 55-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum.  The Belmont Forum is a consortium of research funding organizations focused on support for transdisciplinary approaches to global environmental change challenges and opportunities.  It aims to accelerate delivery of the international research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries.  The teams will establish transdisciplinary networks to develop innovative solutions for sustainable development pathways and seek to assess the positive and negative inter-linkages between the economy, technology, institutions with the environment, climate, biodiversity, and human well-being to understand potential pathways to a sustainable world.

The project seeks to determine the social, economic, and ecological challenges and their interdependencies affect the sustainability of African cities.  The project will develop and work with urban community networks in six representative African cities networks to develop potential pathways to foster sustainability of these and other African cities.  The project will assess the social, economic and ecological assets of these cities and determine how these assets are distributed in space and time.  This data will help the project reframe the question from “what city communities do not have” to “what city communities have” for building synergies and interdependencies. The project will utilize ground-truthed, satellite images, social and ecological facilities and participatory geographic information systems, maps of community spaces of interest, along with data from and extensive review of existing urban policies, directives, and by-laws, to build potential sustainability pathways. The stakeholders will then localize and downscale the plans from global to national level, and from national to community level. Based on these findings and experiences, plausible scenarios for sustainable African cities will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Accomplishments of UComNetSus-Africa project

Major activities
In mid-2021, the project rolled out an activity implementation plan. Six African cities namely, Lagos, Kigali, Kumasi, Nairobi, Dar es Salaam and Mombasa were selected for implementing the five major projects activities namely; Stakeholder Workshops, Focus Group Discussion (FGDs), Participatory Mapping, Waste Management Training, and Art-based Sustainability Workshops. The research team jointly developed a common implementation methodology and protocols for each of the five major activities to enable comparability. First, each principal investigator organized a stakeholder workshop for the respective cities, targeting managerial level personnel that make policies and critical decisions (tier 1 stakeholders). The objective of the stakeholder workshop was to bring together city actors from public, private and non-governmental sectors to discuss the challenges facing the rapidly urbanizing continent and the respective opportunities. Secondly, FGDs were conducted in the focus cities with an aim of capturing the perceptions, knowledge, and experiences of how rapid urbanisation was derailing achievement of sustainable development goals (SDGs) in cities and the practices and suggestions to counter the derailment. In participatory mapping, human visual power in spatial orientation was connected to lived experiences through ‘locovocalization’- attaching mean to spatial outputs. Waste management trainings were conducted in cities targeting small scale waste managers such as youth groups, women groups and other forms of community-based organisations (tier 2 stakeholders). The fact that cities consume over 70% of global natural resources and generate about 70% of global waste, rationalizes human capacity development in the sector. Waste management trainers were sourced from industry and academia to give experiential learning and acquire problem-solving skills and techniques. In the tail end of the project, the art-based sustainability workshops were conducted targeting primary school pupils (tier 3 stakeholders) in the target cities. The aim of the workshop was to formally involve children in the sustainability debate as a way of revealing intergenerational differences in perspectives.

Significant results and outputs
The three-year project results indicated that: 1) African cities have strong colonial history and culture that is today reflected in form of social and economic segregation; 2) most of African cities were grappling with the Big Five problems namely unmanaged waste, scarcity of clean water supply, water and air pollution, grabbing of public urban spaces, and unstable energy supplies characterized by frequent power outages; 3) the youth are using technologies to turn ‘waste to resource’ and they require an enabling financial and technical infrastructure to become successful ‘wastepreneurs’; 4) urban residents co-produce knowledge and solutions for attaining sustainability under local contexts; 5) the young generation is visionary and assertive in claiming their space for entrenching sustainability in their lived urban spaces; 6) participatory urban spatial planning, service delivery, and sustainability are intertwine and define the morphology of future cities. The main project outputs are; a) an established network of over 150 stakeholder organisations; b) spatial maps of problem hotspots; c) a database of city actors from government agencies, corporates and communities organisations; d) conference presentations, newsletters, written reports and short videos; and e) 3 forthcoming scientific publications, book chapter and a policy brief.

Conclusion
The UComNetSus-Africa project laid a strong foundation for urban sustainability research and development in Africa. Co-production of knowledge and co-designing of envisaged African cities were critical in responding to urban problems that were anchored on the unique histories and urbanization trajectories. Stakeholder mobilization remained crucial for leveraging on internal capacities that build on overall synergies and minimization of tradeoffs. Overall, institutional harmony and coexistence of different urban players is a recipe for urban sustainability development where cities and their communities become inclusive, safe, and resilient.
